Award.AwardTitle: Conference: U.S. Workshop on DNA Banking - January 2013, St. Louis, Missouri
Award.AbstractNarration:
A two-day workshop on DNA banking in the US is planned for January 2013, in St. Louis, Missouri, organized by the Missouri Botanical Garden. Among the 26 invitees will be those from institutions having and lacking DNA collections; botanists, zoologists, mycologists, and specialists in bioinformatics, including people at all career stages, will attend; representatives of large and small institutions, including universities and stand-alone natural history museums and herbaria, will be invited. Presentations will be given in the morning and afternoons will be devoted to discussion; 18 of the invitees will be asked to speak. Topics will focus on two themes, maximizing the utility and efficiency of operation of existing DNA collections, and identifying and filling the most critical gaps in those collections.

The objectives of the workshop include improving awareness of existing DNA resources, identifying geographic and taxonomic gaps in those resources and crafting a strategy for filling the gaps, and discussion of what legal, ethical, and data standards should apply to all such resources. The outcomes of the workshop will be published by the Missouri Botanical Garden Press (manuscript editing will be complete within a year of the workshop).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sequencing of genetic information contained in DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is critical to many aspects of modern biology. For example, DNA sequences are now used in virtually all studies of how species are related, which in turn support research in fields such as agriculture and conservation biology. DNA sequences can also be used to identify organisms, and so to ensure that processed products such as fish filets, hardwoods, or herbal supplements are correctly identified. Recent technology has made sequencing cheaper, while field work to collect samples has become more expensive and sometimes harder to arrange. Thus, the limits on how many and which species can be included in a research study are increasingly set by the time and cost of field work.

DNA banking preserves tissue samples in a condition that will allow high-quality DNA to be obtained many years later. This practice can make samples quickly and affordably available to researchers, removing the field-work obstacle. However, existing DNA banks contain only a small fraction of the world’s species, and their collections are often underutilized.

The U.S. Workshop on DNA Banking, held in St. Louis in January 2013, brought together representatives of institutions with large DNA banks and experts in a wide variety of organisms, including plants, fungi, vertebrate animals, insects and spiders, jellyfish, and plankton, to discuss DNA banking in the United States. Nine students participated in the workshop. Subjects of discussion included good management and sample handling practices; networking of banks to make collections easier to use; and the need for expanded collections to respond to the expected future needs of the American research community.

Several participants also spoke at a follow-up symposium at the Botany 2014 conference, which focused on issues important to botanists, such as proper storage conditions for plant samples. A proceedings volume including a range of useful information on DNA banking has been published, with the first copies distributed at Botany 2014.

A white paper of recommendations arising from discussions at the workshop was included in the proceedings volume and is available on the iDigBio website. The white paper offers a list of practical and technical recommendations for DNA bank management, and calls for increased networking among banks and improved online access to databases of their holdings. As a first step, iDigBio has set up a page listing and linking to known repositories.

A major theme of discussion was that today’s collections must expand greatly to meet the needs of future researchers. Very few samples are available for some important groups, including fungi and many very small organisms. It was therefore recommended that a long-term goal be set of making all species native to or naturalized in the U.S. available in DNA banks. The government of Norway has a similar goal, but their flora and fauna are much smaller than ours. Pursuit of this goal in the U.S. would require a combination of long-term support for general collecting in critical habitats and encouragement for all biologists to actively seek opportunities to donate samples to DNA banks. If successful, it would ensure that access to samples will never be an obstacle to continued cutting-edge research on our own flora and fauna.
